title: The Case of the Missing C#
chief_complaint: I don't enjoy playing the piano anymore because the notes around C# sound slightly 'flat', even though I just had the piano tuned. The higher-pitched notes on the right side of the keyboard also sound 'thin'.

problem_summary.onset: Noticed recently after retirement when playing piano more frequently.
problem_summary.course: Persistent; piano tuning did not resolve the issue.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Pitch distortion (dyplacusis), perception of sounds being 'flat' or 'thin'.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Loss of enjoyment in musical hobbies (piano playing).
problem_summary.goals_motivation: To enjoy playing music again without distortion.

history.present_illness: Patient reports specific distortion with the note C# on the piano (sounding flat) and high notes sounding thin.
history.noise_exposure_history: Worked in noisy environments; avid gun enthusiast.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function. Ear canal volume, static compliance, and middle ear pressure within normal limits.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Elevated at 500 and 1000 Hz; absent at 2000 and 4000 Hz.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral symmetrical mild to profound high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Sharply falling configuration beyond 500-1000 Hz, flat to 3000 Hz, falling again to 6000 Hz, with recovery at 8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs suggest moderate to severe loss (likely influenced by slope). Word recognition scores are excellent in quiet.

tests.name: Pitch Perception / Piano Test
tests.key_findings: Patient played piano to identify problematic notes. C# notes at 277, 554, and 1109 Hz caused difficulty (sounded flat). Higher frequency C# (2218 Hz) and High C (4186 Hz) sounded 'thin' but not flat.

history.present_illness: Fitting appointment. Addressing the 'flat' sound quality in music.
history.patient_goals: Adjust hearing aids to improve piano sound quality.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Initial fit matched NAL-NL2 targets well. Systematic gain reduction was performed to identify the frequency region causing distortion. Reducing gain at fundamental C# (274 Hz) and first harmonic (554 Hz) did not help. Notch filtering at the higher harmonic region (1000-1500 Hz) resolved the issue.

numeric_results.Final_Adjustment: 15 dB notch filter between 1000 Hz and 1500 Hz
numeric_results.Target_Match: Good match to NAL-NL2 prior to notch filtering

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral, symmetrical, high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, characterized by a steep slope beyond 1000 Hz and recovery at 8000 Hz. Despite excellent word recognition in quiet, the unaided Speech Intelligibility Index is low (14%). The patient exhibits dyplacusis (pitch distortion), perceiving specific musical notes (C#) as 'flat', likely due to cochlear dead regions or significant hair cell damage in the 1000–2000 Hz range.
counseling_points: Your hearing loss is concentrated in the high frequencies, which explains why speech isn't clear in noise and why high piano notes sound 'thin'.
The 'flat' sound you hear when playing C# is called dyplacusis. This happens when damage to the inner ear causes the pitch to be perceived incorrectly.
We believe the distortion is coming from the harmonics of the note, rather than the fundamental note itself.

To fix this, we have programmed a 'notch' in your hearing aids to reduce amplification specifically in the 1000–1500 Hz range. This removes the distorted information while keeping other sounds audible.
notes_for_actor: You are a knowledgeable amateur musician. You know your piano is in tune, so you are confused and frustrated that it sounds 'flat'.
Be specific about the note C#. It's not just 'music sounds bad'; it is specifically that note.
You have a history of noise exposure (guns, work), so you might expect some hearing loss, but the pitch distortion is the most bothersome symptom.
